ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly improved my research skills, as well as my ability to write clearly, concisely, and effectively for the point I am trying to convey.
writing, critical thinking, analysis, research

This class helped to improve my writing skills immensely by helping me get a better grip of the writing process (i.e. bringing in small portions of a paper at a time, outlining, etc.) and giving me ways to fix what I have already written (i.e. organization, wordiness, sentence structure).

I improved my entire writing process, from planning to drafting to revising. In particular, I think my ability to analyze texts improved drastically. I also had strong improvement in the structure of my writing, such as with formulating an argument. We also read a number of interesting academic articles on hope theory which helped me improve my reading comprehension and analysis.

I learned a more concrete definition of hope, and I also developed my writing. More specifically, my writing got a lot better on a sentence level and I learned to be more specific/accurate in the way I am presenting information.

I obtained knowledge about what it means to write a research paper from brainstorming ideas to finding sources to writing out several pages of a full research paper. I also got insights in detail with clear examples for revision, concise writing, body paragraphs, introductions, writing style, and tone.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: great readings, great teacher, compelling topic
weaknesses: can't think of any

I really appreciated the pace of this course. We took our time to write our papers with lots of feedback along the way. As a usually last minute writer, this was very useful. We also got a lot of opportunities to talk about our papers one-on-one with individual conferences which was very useful, especially over zoom.

This course had no real weaknesses in my eyes besides the fact that it was virtual. The course had a number of strengths. First off, through in class activities, homework assignments, and writing assignments, I definitely improved my writing. The course readings were also fairly interesting, and they covered a wide-variety of topics. The professor was also very accessible, and this definitely allowed for an easier learning process. Finally, the small discussion format made the class very engaging and allowed me to get to know people in the class.

Strengths: small size of the class (we were only 6 or 7!), very engaging for a zoom seminar (lots of different activities, breakout rooms, peer editing, etc). Another big strength was the topic of the class! It was so interesting to learn about hope from an academic perspective and also from a personal perspective. And of course, Sam was incredible. He clearly cared about all of us as people and as students, and truly made my experience in 114 amazing. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes it felt like the time allotted to peer-review essay portions was a bit short/rushed. Making the breakouts even 5 minutes longer would be helpful.

The strengths of this course are the seminar style and the way how it is set up to usually let the student read the information/advice for writing, discuss it, and sometimes use the skill. That way the things that are taught in theory can clarified and tested out. I think the course's weaknesses are that the times that we can test out the theoretical ideas and skills are dependent on what we write and revise in our peers' work. When we send in our drafts, we don't get direct, applicable feedback for stuff related to the skills we learned in class. It would be better if the feedback were more tied somehow to the things that we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom classes were hard at times but overall pretty enjoyable

I appreciated the small course size and opportunities for individual feedback. I also really liked using google drive since it is both very easy to navigate, update, and collaborate on. Zoom is a difficult platform for seminars and I would prefer to have a class like this in person but it was very well done for the circumstances.

I don't think the zoom room quite replicated a classroom, but I think it made the best of a tough situation. It was very easy to access online course materials. We mostly worked over google drive which worked just fine.

Many successes! This was one of few zoom classes that I genuinely enjoyed because it involved so much student participation and a large variety of activities. We were never doing any one thing for too long, which is especially important on zoom.
The class setup to put all the files and syllabus in a google drive was a really great and useful plan. The files, class notes, syllabus, and assignments were easily accessible.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I cannot speak for the other TAs, but mine was absolutely fantastic.
yes, great to get a writing credit and interesting topics

I would recommend this course to another student. I think we had lots of levels of writing skill in our class and everyone benefitted from it. There are a lot of things that are simply hard to pick out in your own writing and the collaborative nature of this class, both with the instructor and with other students, really help you learn what those faults in your own writing are.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Writing in college is hard, and this course really helped me improve my writing ability. The course is interesting, the professor is great, and you will get a lot out of it. Highly recommend.
YES!!! It was not too stressful (because of how understanding Sam was), but at the same time I learned so much, had a lot of fun, and really improved my writing!
I would recommend this course to another student especially if they are interested in learning how to write research papers and similar papers.
